Under Indian parliamentary democracy, is it possible to ensure balanced regional development? Please elaborate with reasons and examples.

Yes, it is possible to ensure balanced regional development under Indian parliamentary democracy. In democracy every one has a right to express his/her thoughts and problems. The government of India has appointed Raghu ram Rajan committee to rate the development of the state under 10 rate weighted scale. By this the Government of  India gets the clear image of the status of the regions. Based on that the Government of India can take necessary steps  for the balanced development of the regions.

The concerned member of the parliament  and the central minister of   that  particular region has to address the issues and the backwardness of the region in the parliament .

  In Andhra Pradesh, telangana region is less developed . As the major resources are available in the particular region but the it has been not beneficial for the people of telangana.

 Eg: Nizam sugar factory in Medak (dist) , a decade ago it was a public ltd company.  A few years back it has been privatized and now it has been closed. In this particular district maximum percentage of the people  depends on the agriculture ,this district is suitable for the cultivation of sugar cane.

  By this people has lost their jobs and farmers  didn't find alternative solution , most of them  stopped  cultivation of the crop and moved to the urban areas for the work(employment).

 The issue  of backward ness of telangana has been raised  in the parliament of India. It has been discussed thoroughly in the parliament ,for the development of the particular region  government of India has bifracuvated the  Andhra Pradesh.

  After bifracuation of Andhra Pradesh ,for  the development of Andhra Pradesh  the government of India has been giving the special package for Seem Andhra development.

 By this both the regions will be developed equally and simultaneously.

 Eg 2:Gurkaland in West Bengal.

In West Bengal Gurka land is less developed, when compare to other parts of the Bengal. The   member of parliament of the  West Bengal has raised the issue about the backwardness of the Gurka land in Bengal. The MP's has agreed about the  backwardness of the particular region, some of them have demanded for the  separate state and others demanded for the special package.

Government of India is working on this issue for giving a special package for the development of particular region.

By this in my view I ensure that balanced regional development is possible through the Indian Parliamentary
